hu.kazocsaba.memento

Class Memento

  • java.lang.Object
    • hu.kazocsaba.memento.Memento
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<Memento>

    public class Memento
extends Object
implements Iterable<Memento>
    A class storing key-value mappings. Keys are always String objects; a few simple value data types are supported. null keys and values are not allowed.

    A memento can have child mementos; these are stored in creation order, and enable building a hierarchy to represent complex data structures. For example, if a single memento holds the data of a person, child mementos can be used to store a list of persons. 

        private void saveInto(Person person, Memento target) {
        target.putString("name", person.getName());
        target.putInt("age", person.getAge());
    }
    private Memento save(List<Person> people) {
        Memento m = new Memento();
        for (Person person: people) {
            Memento personMemento = m.createChild("person");
            saveInto(person, personMemento);
        }
        return m;
    }

    Each memento can have a string type that can be used to differentiate between various kinds of child mementos. The following code restores the list of persons. 

        private List<Person> load(Memento m) throws MementoFormatException {
        List<Person> people = new ArrayList<>();
        // iterate over the child mementos
        for (Memento child: m) {
            // only process the children with the type "person"
            if ("person".equals(child.getType()))
                people.add(new Person(child.getString("name"), child.getInt("age")));
        }
        return people;
    }

    This class allows later versions of a program to load mementos created by previous versions. If a new property has been introduced, its existence can be tested using hasProperty(String), or (in simple cases) a default value can be used in case the property is missing. For example: 

        // if preferred language is missing, use default value
    String lang = personMemento.getString("preferred language", "English");
 
    if (!personMemento.hasProperty("address")) {
        // handle missing address
    }

    In general, queries for properties that are non-existent or that have a type different from the one requested are considered a format error and result in MementoFormatException.

    Author:
    Kaz√≥ Csaba

      • getFirstChild

        public Memento getFirstChild()
                      throws MementoFormatException
        Returns the first child of this memento. This is a convenience method for cases when the memento should have exactly one child.
        Returns:
        the first child of the memento
        Throws:
        MementoFormatException - if this memento has no children

      • getFirstChildWithType

        public Memento getFirstChildWithType(String type)
                              throws MementoFormatException
        Returns the first child of this memento with the specified type.
        Parameters:
        type - the type; can be null
        Returns:
        the first child of the memento with the given type
        Throws:
        MementoFormatException - if this memento has no child with the given type

      • createChild

        public Memento createChild()
        Creates a new child of this memento. The new child will be the last of this memento's children.
        Returns:
        the newly created child memento

      • createChild

        public Memento createChild(String type)
        Creates a new child of this memento. The new child will be the last of this memento's children.
        Parameters:
        type - the type of the child memento; can be null
        Returns:
        the newly created child memento

      • copyFrom

        public void copyFrom(Memento memento)
        Copies the parameter memento into this one. First the properties are added to this (overwriting any existing properties in case of a conflict), then child mementos are created corresponding to the argument's children, and each child is copied in the same fashion.
        Parameters:
        memento - the memento to copy into this

      • iterator

        public Iterator<Memento> iterator()
        Returns the same as iterateChildren().
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Iterable<Memento>
        Returns:
        an iterator over the child mementos
